Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Monumental Architecture And Social Organization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Prehistoric Mayans provide an excellent example of a culture which, with relatively simple technology, was able to create societies which included multiple thousands of individuals and allow them to function successfully in a physical environment which supports lower population densities today. Researchers wish to understand the social mechanisms - some political and others economic - which facilitated this adaptation. This research project achieves significance within this context.

La Milpa is one of the largest ancient Maya sites in Belize, and was occupied from the Late Preclassic to the Terminal Classic (approximately 250 BC to AD 850). Structure 3 is a temple pyramid and one of the largest structures at the site, built initially around 250 BC, and renovated multiple times over its history. Under the supervision of Dr Fred Valdez, and guidance from Dr Sheryl Luzzadder-Beach and Dr Paul Goldberg, Debora Trein will examine the possible functions of Structure 3 by analyzing the distribution of microscopic remains of activities in and around this building, in conjunction with a traditional examination of artifact assemblages and the architectural morphology of the structure. Ms. Trein will examine the patterns of activities at Structure 3 by employing Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS), sediment micromorphology, and AMS radiocarbon dating in the analysis of samples gathered during the 2012 and 2013 field seasons.

Ancient monumental architecture is a research topic that has received sustained academic attention. Nevertheless, the approach adopted in this project provides a new perspective on the subject, primarily for two reasons. First, this research will analyze archaeological evidence at the microscopic level, in the shape of chemical signatures and micromorphological traits of sediments associated with particular activities. These types of evidence are seldom used in a discussion of the functions of monumental architecture in the Maya region, even though these may be just as indicative of variability of ancient space use as the architecture itself. Second, studies of monumental architecture in the Maya region have generally focused on the intentions of its architects, who are assumedly of elite status. This project aims to complement these studies by focusing also on the actual use of Structure 3 by its community, as suggested by the remains of activities that may include such mundane acts as cooking and tool-making. In doing so, this research seeks to inform on how various groups of agents, possibly of diverse social and economic backgrounds, shaped this monumental structure and its functions.

This project aims to have broader impacts beyond the intellectual benefits presented. During the 2012 and 2013 field seasons, undergraduate students from the United States and local staff received training in geochemical and micromorphology sampling. These educational opportunities will be expanded in the future. Ms. Trein will hold workshops on retrieval and analysis of geochemical and micromorphology samples for undergraduate students, local staff, and the surrounding community at Programme for Belize Archaeological Project (PfBAP), in Belize. It is hoped that this public outreach effort will foster community understanding and engagement in archaeology, and provide an educational opportunity for those who may be interested in pursuing a career in archaeology. The results from this project will be disseminated in peer-reviewed publications and presentations at symposia in the United States and abroad, promoting academic scholarship and collaboration. The raw data produced by this research will be freely and widely available through the University of Texas Digital Repository (UTDR).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The authors (Fred Valdez Jr. and Debora Trein) are in the process of completing the analysis of the geochemical and sediment micromorphology component of Trein’s dissertation work, analyses that were funded by a NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant. This dissertation concerns the variable ways in which a monumental temple pyramid (Structure 3) was accessed and used by its community between the Late Preclassic (ca. 250 BCE to 250 CE) and the Late and Terminal Classic (ca. 550 CE to 850 CE) periods at the Maya site of La Milpa, in Belize. Radiocarbon dating of several archaeological deposits associated with this large structure was also undertaken utilizing NSF funds. During the period of the grant, the author focused on drying, processing, and preparing samples for shipment and analysis, as well as interpreting the results where these were available.

 

Nine charcoal and burned sediment samples collected from Structure 3 for AMS radiocarbon analysis were processed by Debora Trein in a laboratory at UT Austin. Sediment and extraneous matter were separated from charcoal and burned sediment using sterile tools. Appropriate samples (approximately 1 g) of each specimen were separated, catalogued, repackaged, and shipped to the UC Irvine W. M. Keck Carbon Cycle Accelerator Mass Spectrometry Laboratory, where they were analyzed by Dr. John Southoun in Spring 2015. The results showed that the temple and its surroundings had been used and accessed by its community since at least ca. 350 CE. Results also suggested that the structure was terminated and subsequently abandoned as early as 660 CE and as late as ca. 755 CE, although use of the areas surrounding the temple pyramid may have continued for at least a century after the “closing down” of Structure 3.

 

Collected from the research area in 2014, 19 sediment cores were repackaged and shipped to Spectrum Petrographics, where they were impregnated in resin and cut into 33 thin sections in Fall 2014 and Spring 2015. The analysis of these thin sections is ongoing, but the author expects to gather information about the nature of the use and access of the areas surrounding Structure 3.

 

The 130 loose sediment samples collected from Structure 3 and its surroundings were dried by Debora Trein in a laboratory at UT Austin. As X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) and X-Ray Fluorescence (XRF) were also to be undertaken on the sediment collected, a 10 g “sub-sample” was separated from each sample for XRF and XRD. Once sub-sampling was complete, the remainder of the 130 samples was sent to the Cornell University Soil Health Laboratory for soil fertility and total elemental analysis/heavy metal tests utilizing Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS) and Inductively Coupled Atomic Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-AES). The results of the geochemical analysis conducted by Cornell was received in June 2015, and the interpretation of this data is ongoing.

 

This research will provide a baseline for the application of sediment micromorphology as a methodology for the study of activity areas in ancient monumental contexts in the Maya region, activities that may have been mundane as well as extraordinary in character. Moreover, the geochemical data gathered and interpreted over the course of this project will contribute to the growing body of information of the range and applicability of geochemical analysis in the Maya area, which is still a budding field. As the nature of this project necessitates the correlation of multiple lines of evidence (architectural, artifact, geochemical and micromorphological), this project contributes to the building of a dataset framework that may be employed in investigating activity areas in the Maya region and beyond.
